title: DragonForce's Herman Li: Does It Really Matter If You Know Music Theory [News]
text:
10 
DragonForce guitarist Herman Li discussed his knowledge of musical theory, telling UG interviewer Steven Rosen: 
"[DragonForce bassist] Fred [Leclercq] is really good at telling me [when a solo is bad] because he studied music and he sees music in a different way than I see music because I never studied music. 
"I learned scales, arpeggios and some music theory but I don't see it in the same way as say someone who studied music. 
"Not that they all sound the same but I'm just saying people who studied music see things differently than I do and [guitarist] Sam [Totman] does as well. Fred would say, 'On ' The Last Journey Home ' [off 2008's ' Ultra Beatdown '] - that is wrong.' He tells us stuff like that or 'That's not the right chord with those notes.' 
"I go, 'No one complained on the album so we should keep playing it wrong live' and he goes, 'No, we shouldn't.' 
"I say, 'It's my sound,' so it's kind of a weird thing. I don't just play all the solos and say that's it. I do let people give me an opinion. 
Focusing on the quality of studio recordings, Mr. Li noted: "You can always do better but the problem is what is better? It's hard to say. You listen to some albums and it's not perfect and you go, 'That√≠s amazing.' You do perfect stuff and say, 'That sounds boring.' 
"That's the problem with music - it's so subjective and the feeling and all that is very different. You listen to it tomorrow or the next day and you go, 'Oh, that's actually fine.' Personally, I have a different attitude now. I just say, 'Eh.' I don't really get frustrated, I just do it again until it sounds right."
